G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as this matter concerns a residential tenancy and claim arising under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of rented premises is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The city inspector confirmed the existence of water infiltration and cited the property for violations of the Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including failure to maintain the foundation in a watertight condition.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable and watertight condition constitutes an interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns landlord liability for excessive noise from a lounge the landlord leased and could control, as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. The opinion does not address failures to maintain premises in a habitable or watertight physical condition (e.g., leaks, structural defects); instead, it deals with noise disturbances as the interfering condition. Using Blackett as authority specifically for the proposition that failure to keep premises habitable and watertight constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment misstates the case’s holding, though its reasoning might be analogized.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: As in Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), prolonged failure to remedy recurring leaks and water damage constitutes a disturbance of a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly treats the repeated flooding and water intrusion as an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and under the common-law covenant. It holds that the landlord’s failure over a “long and repetitious course” to correct the porous wall and prevent recurrent flooding constituted a disturbance of quiet enjoyment, warranting statutory liability and attorneys’ fees, even though the separate quiet-enjoyment damages award was later vacated as duplicative.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent…. The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes unlawful interference where her retaliatory statements and intent not to renew were prompted by Plaintiff’s lawful complaint to authorities, violating G.L. c. 186, § 18, and demonstrating willful disregard of Plaintiff’s rights.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Pursuant to Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), a tenant need not abandon the premises to claim violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, by itself, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and what level of landlord fault is required. It does not address whether a tenant must abandon or vacate the premises in order to claim a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Because the opinion segment does not discuss abandonment or continued occupancy at all, it cannot be relied on as authority for the stated proposition.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: "Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures."

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant’s neglect of the water infiltration violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the state sanitary code provisions at 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring maintenance of foundation and structural elements in a watertight condition).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Defendant’s neglect of the water infiltration violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the state sanitary code provisions at 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring maintenance of foundation and structural elements in a watertight condition).

105 C.M.R. 410.500.proposition: Defendant’s neglect of the water infiltration violated her statutory duties under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, G.L. c. 111, § 127A, and the state sanitary code provisions at 105 C.M.R. 410.500 (requiring maintenance of foundation and structural elements in a watertight condition).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct meets the standard of interference with quiet enjoyment recognized in Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994), where a landlord’s omissions that materially impair a tenant’s use of premises are actionable.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s covenant of quiet enjoyment to cover a landlord’s omissions that result in serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises. The court holds that if the landlord “failed to take any action or inadequate action” to remove persons whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ ability to use common areas, this may breach quiet enjoyment—i.e., omissions that materially impair use are actionable. This aligns with the proposition that the defendant’s conduct can meet the Doe standard where landlord omissions materially impair use of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold…. If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Gabler v. Naiman, 402 Mass. 224 (1988).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that water leaks, dampness, and failure to repair code violations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Gabler v. Naiman, 402 Mass. 224 (1988).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity of amendments to a business trust, fiduciary duties of trustees and custodians, and the authority to diminish preferred shareholders’ rights. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, water leaks, dampness, or housing code violations. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts treat those habitability problems as a breach of quiet enjoyment.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that water leaks, dampness, and failure to repair code violations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that financial inability is not a defense. It does not, however, address water leaks, dampness, or failure to repair code violations generally; its discussion is confined to lack of heat. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the broader proposition that Massachusetts courts have consistently held water leaks, dampness, and failure to repair code violations to be breaches of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that water leaks, dampness, and failure to repair code violations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez affirms liability for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and for breach of quiet enjoyment generally, but it does not specifically discuss water leaks, dampness, or code-violation repairs as the basis for a covenant of quiet enjoyment claim. The decision focuses on lack of heat, severe unsanitary and unsafe conditions, harassment, and emotional distress, and its detailed legal analysis is about c. 93A damages and habitability, not a consistent Massachusetts rule about water leaks/dampness constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims.

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory threats and interference, following Plaintiff’s lawful complaint to city inspectors, further violate the tenant protections embodied in G.L. c. 186, § 14, and Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983).
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O’Brien interprets public-housing ‘good cause’ eviction standards under G.L. c. 121B, § 32 and related regulations; it does not involve or construe G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address retaliatory threats or interference following a tenant’s lawful complaint to city inspectors. The case is about a tenant’s responsibility for a household member’s drug activity and the sufficiency of cause and notice for eviction, not about retaliation for protected tenant activity. Accordingly, it does not provide authority that retaliatory threats or interference violate the tenant protections of c. 186, § 14.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
“O’Brien’s eviction is founded upon ‘good cause reasonably related to the protection of some legitimate interest of the public landlord.’ Spence v. Reeder, 382 Mass. at 420.”

“The record before us reveals that all the procedural requirements set out in 24 C.F.R. § 866.54 through and including § 866.58 (1982) were followed. O’Brien’s remaining contentions concerning whether the panel’s decision constituted good cause have been answered in Spence v. Gormley, supra.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B from the date of injury.
